description.text:
Case for iPhone 5 with a cut out duck shape.
Modified iPhone 5 Bunny Case by virtualmagician.

This script creates a mount for the MatterControl Touch tablet for attaching to a 3D printer. In this case, a Mini Kossel but it can be adapted for any printer.  
I created this thing so that I can mount my MatterControl Touch to the printer in place of the LCD panel. If you haven't used one of these before, you will be amazed at its power, ease of use, and convenience.   
Now when my print is done, MatterControl Touch can take a photo of the print and email it to me! Better still, once the remote access features are released, I'll be able to check on my printer remotely. The added bonus is I can move my MatterControl Touch to any of my other printers, clip it in, plug it up, and start printing!  
How cool is that?  
Disclaimer: I do not profit by promoting this device. I am merely a very satisfied customer. ;)

You can modify this script to change the mount if you want a different type - clamp or whatever. You can also change the length of the arm if you want the table to be further away from the print bed. Feel free to customize at will! Vitamins: (2) M3 nylock nuts
(2) M3 nuts
(2) 15x30mm strips of self adhesive foam ~1/8" thick
(4) M3 washers
(1) M3x25mm bolt
(1) M3x50mm bolt
(2) M3x8mm bolts
(1) MatterControl Touch ;) Note: You may be able to substitute #6 bolts for the longer M3, but you may need to drill out the holes a bit. Or, better, modify the code to use larger holes.
  • Print (1) arm, (1) mount, and (2) clips. PLA is fine. I would use 0.3 layer height and 40% infill for strength. No supports are needed. There are pads on the clip at key locations to help prevent lifting. Just cut those away when printed.
  • Attach the mount to the printer using (2) M3x8 bolts and (2) M3 nuts.
  • Attach the arm to the mount using (1) M3x25 bolt, (2) M3 washers and (1) M3 nylock. Do not tighten, just snug the bolt.
  • Attach the clips to either side of the arm using (1) M3x50 bolt, (2) M3 washers, and (1) M3 nylock. Do not tighten, just snug the bolt.
  • Attach foam strips.
  • Clip the MatterControl Touch into the clip, position, and tighten the bolts. Tip: Use the camera preview to sight your build plate.

description.text:
I just got back from California and decided to make myself a souvenir from my trip that I couldn't buy if I wanted to. So here it is! My Miniature In-N-Out sign (with a 4mm hole on the base of the sign for mounting on a dowel rod for display).  
I printed this as a one dual extrusion print, but it could just as easily be printed in parts using a single extruder printer (see my instructions for details).   
Now if I could only print myself a double double...

• Assign InNOut_BoxSingle_TNH.stl to your first extruder. Assign InNOut_Arrow_TNH.stl to your second extruder.
  • Pause your print at 8mm and swap your first extruder from red to white.

• Print InNOut_Arrow_TNH.stl in yellow.
  • Print InNOut_BoxSingle_TNH.stl, pausing and swapping red for white filament at 8mm.
  • Glue the top and bottom arrow sections to the main body.

description.text:
This is one of a series of wheel prototypes FRC team 2363 delevoped. This wheel is for a 1/2" hex shaft. It uses 1 1/2" wide tread. When the tread is attached, the OD would be ~4".  
The spokes on this wheel are .096" thick and wide.  A previous version used .063" spokes, but these spokes were too delicate to survive removal of the support structure.  As removed from the printer bed, weight was 87gm.  With the external support structure removed (as much as would be removed if there were inner and outer fairings), weight was 66gm.  When all support structure was removed, weight was 54gm.  
In ReplicatorG software, the wheel goes face down on the bed, and is grown using "full support". This keeps the upper lip of the rim and the spokes properly supported.  
This wheel uses the same hub and rim as the "Mag" wheel, from which it was derived.

This thing is pretty useless. There are far better designs out there that you should be looking at instead. For .75 inch FSR.
Added openscad file so you can customize it for different beams, screws and FSR.
Mounts on the inside of the openbeam and has a lip to support a circular disk to shield electronics and motors from the heated bed.

There are 4 variables in the scad file that you can modify to fit your needs.
fsr_diam; The diameter of your FSR. Default is .75in (19.1mm) which fits the FSR bought from tridprinting and ultibots
cube_side; Set width/depth of FSR mount
beam_height; Set height of FSR mount. 15 for Openbeam, change to whatever fits your beams.
screw_diameter; Set diameter of the screw used to attach FSR mount to your beam. I print using the standar kossel mini settings from the reprap wiki;
Layer height = 0.2 to 0.3 mm (around 60% of your nozzle size)
Perimeters = 3
Top/bottom solid layers = 3
Infill density = 50%
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/b2YvdiFkJ5H

description.text: Designed for the Plastic scribbler, which has only a threaded bar to hold the filament spools. This will fit any spool with a 2.25 inch inner diameter.

As if there were not enough creative spool holders out there... here's another one :)
This will fit spools up to 190mm diameter.
The width is adjustable. It's one of those meta-prints that one has to give a try at some point and I felt inspired by the brilliant ball-bearing and the sidemounted spoolholder found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:56298 and here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:312624 It all prints without support and it should be very easy to assemble.
Check "Instructions" for parts list.

Parts needed:
2 x http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:56298 2 x http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:312624 (just the flange aka "Filament_hub"-file is needed, either 38mm or 48mm, check your spool!). 20 x 6mm softgun "bullets" (the yellow balls you see in the picture where the ballbearing is showing). 4 x M3 bolt 25mm
4 x M3 hex nut

This is the Ultimaker temperature sensor (version 1) that is based on the AD597. It amplifies the signal from a type K thermocouple and has the same mV/K output as the polular AD595 board that is used in many RepRap projects. It's about the size of a thumbnail (hence the out-of-focus picture). The amp chip is an SOT-8. The screw terminals are extra small (2.54 mm pitch) and holes are M3. They were designed in Eagle CAD by Siert Wijnia and myself. The files are found here on the RepRap wiki:
http://www.reprap.org/wiki/File:Thermocouple_board_v0.4.sch
http://www.reprap.org/wiki/File:Thermocouple_board_v0.4.brd It has a nice bright blue LED, great for long exposure photography of a print (for moving head machines). The picture with the lit LED is a prototype made with the help of Jelle, who's also designer of the UltiRouter: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7110 Separate sensor boards (pre-assembled) will be available within a month or two. On request we can also offer the PCBs in quantities of 20 and more. FIXES in the next release:
  • A ground plane!
  • Pads on the other side so you can decide where to mount the terminals or headers.

From the outside to the inside of the board, the connections are labeled: -, + and S on the side that goes to the main PCB, on the thermocouple sensor side they are labeled + and -. For instructions on how to hook them up to your analog inputs, please see this page:
http://www.reprap.org/wiki/Ultimaker%27s_v1.5.3_PCB#Add-ons

title: Wingnut caps for platform thumbscrews on FlashForge Creator

description.text:
These wingnut caps are designed to go over the existing thumbscrews for adjusting the heated platform. The thumbscrews are relatively small and can hurt your thumb and fingers. These caps just makes it much easier to adjust.   
Make them out of ABS. Heat up the thumbscrews on a long screw and then press them into the hole. The heat will soften the plastic enough for it to slide in snugly.

This is one of a series of wheel prototypes FRC team 2363 delevoped. This wheel is for a 1/2" hex shaft. It uses 1 3/16" wide tread. When the tread is attached, the OD would be ~4".  
In ReplicatorG software, the wheel goes face down on the bed, and is grown using "full support". This keeps the upper lip of the rim  properly supported.  
This wheel has the same spoked internal structure of the spoked wheel from which it was derived.  Fairings were added to the inner and outer faces to protect the spokes and provide a smooth surface on which to build lettering or a logo in a contrasting color.  The tread was narrowed to better match the Colson wheels we used this year, and to clear some fastener heads on our frame.  
In addition, internal bosses were added for attaching fasteners for mounting the tread.  Four small holes, visible in one of the pictures, show where the bosses are located.  
Weight: 95gm

Two part shell for iPhone 4s that centers the camera in a 56mm eyepiece cup. Suitable for spotting scopes etc. For best results, the iPhone camera must be dead centre and perpendicular to the eyepiece optic. The eyepiece cup depth should be adequate for moving the adaptor to achieve the best field of view. A ring is provided for a lanyard or tether. Requires 4 x M3 Screws cut to length to self tap into front cover part. See : https://tatejoris.wordpress.com/2015/03/16/priceless-digiscoping-adaptor-for-iphone/ for more information

title: Da Vinci Printer 60mm dual fan cooler

description.text:
A dual 60mm fan cooler for the Da Vinci 3d printer.
it helps to solidify the print between layers and helps with overhangs while printing. When printing with PLA,this will help with the overhangs and can speed up your printing time.
You could try it out on ABS but only turn on the fans after a good few layers have been set down on the heated bed. I use an external 12volt molex power supply to power the fans.

i printed this in solid ABS and used two 60mm computer case fans rated at 0.28 amp mounted inside.
i used a rubber band around the enclosure to make a tight fit and create an air seal.
The power switch is rated at 12 volts 6 amp and measures 12mm X 19mm.

This is a tilt adapter for the popular ZMR250 miniquad and FatShark 600TVL camera, but basically any camera with 12 mm lens thread should work. The camera sits behind the tilt adapter and when you screw a lens through the printed part, it will all hold together making a really simple and lightweight tilt solution.  
Tilt part is available as 10, 15 and 20 degree variants.  
Printed in two parts. Rotate parts as required. Angle modules are not in optimal print orientation. Attach together with CA glue or acetone if printed from ABS.  
The multirotor I am using is built with RCTimer 1806 2300kv motors, Sunrise Slim OPTO 20A BLHeli ESCs, the awesome OpenPilot CC3D flight controller and 850mAh 6S battery.
Bepp BEEEEP

I based this upgrade on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:42250 from whpthomas. Please follow his directions for items you need. Changes that I have made:
Shorter arm so that it can fit into the 2X on both sides
Big feed hole
Using the top left and right screw holes to hold the base against the motor
Added a groove so that it is possible to add a screw from the front to keep the arm in position
Added a way to hold a nuts at the back for the two screws that will go through the arm

I used ReplicatorG and I used the default Replicator 1 profile to slice. I am running the latest ReplicatorG and Sailfish For all three items

Makerbot Black ABS For the pin

description.text: The Alibre model is parametric, allowing you to size it to exactly fit your particular 3d printer's table. It is sized to fit my Up! It is designed to be rigid, resisting curling at the corners, while using a minimal amount of material.

Size it to fit your printer's table, and print one out. Use it as a size reference when thinking about what you can make with your printer. Use it to test your printer on large items. I found that the corners curled off of the table some, and there were some splits in the corners partway up the sides. Good to find out before printing something more important.

comments.author: lalbritton

description.text:
Following the ABS Acetone Vapor Treating videos, I saw A.Bowyers post that Dichloromethane works as a PLA solvent.  
I then rushed to buy a glass pot (550ml Weck Jar) and some Dichloromethane.  
Heating the bed up to roughly 100degrees with the lid on produced vapor. And about 2-3 minutes in the vapor smoothed out the part (I didn't time this, just a guess, may have been in there for longer).   
The part was printed in 0.25mm layers and 0.55mm tracks, after vapor treating the part is VERY flexible (rubbery). I will see if this goes away over time.   
The pinky part on top of the gear (M8 nuttrap) is from putting the part down on the heated bed after removing from the vapor. DOH! :)  
UPDATE: After about 18 hours, the part is back to 'almost' being solid again. Just a slight amount of flex. Presumably if you left it in for only a minute, this would take less time to solidify. I did try the small gear for a few seconds by just lowering it into the vapor, there was noticable difference to the layers, but the part remained solid.

Be very careful when using this chemical. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dichloromethane Always use with an open window / adequette ventilation. Or use outside if possible. When lifting the lid of the pot, I held my breath and kept my distance. If possible, make a scoop/hook to remove parts to lessen any exposure of the vapor with your skin. This chemical has been linked to cancer of the lungs, liver, and pancreas in laboratory animals.

comments.text: What about a solvent for filaflex, ninjaflex et al, people? I've done experiments with PLA and got to see that chloroform, dichloromethane and tetrahydrofuran work well, but nothing seems to work with TPU/TPE.
comments.author: Patola

comments.text: has any one tried used a hot air gun to slightly melt the surface and give the same effect?
comments.author: andrewar

comments.text: I think that a hot air gun would heat it too much, and apply too much force (blower) onto the semi-solid part, and cause it to deform. However, it might be worth a try at some point.
comments.author: andrewar

comments.text: PLA is not like ABS, it does not slowly gets softer. PLA has a very well-defined point where it goes from solid to almost liquid with heat, so a hot air gun is a very bad idea.
comments.author: Aggresive

comments.text: It looks really good, but dude you're going to get cancer and die, don't do this without proper safety stuff in place.  This whole setup should be contained in something that vents to somewhere very far away after running through a condenser.  Your interaction should be only through gloves that are built into the enclosure..  I work with dangerous chemicals all the time, and I wouldn't do this without a full on laboratory setup. comments.text: Apparently wikipedia says PLA is also soluble in THF (tetrahydrofuran). If any of you don't know, it's the solvent in pvc cement. That would be pretty cool to try as well. comments.text: Cool man! I've been wondering about dichloromethane and how well it would work. Definitely keep us posted on your progress. Dichloromethane is a fairly rough solvent but the least toxic of all your simple chlorinated hydrocarbons.  It's used in a lot paint strippers among other things. It's boiling point is only about 40 degrees C so don't store in a place that gets hot. The vapors are really strong and as you stated not good for you breath (hard on the eyes too).  However if you use it in a well ventilated area or in a fume hood (assuming your observing proper "lab safety" about the use of solvents) you should be fine. I can't wait till i get my printer in (hopefully next week)!  Oh, and yes, I am a chemist and used dichloromethane extensively as a graduate student.

title: CodeThread - GCode from Processing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
CodeThread is libary for processing that lets you create g-code as you calculate coordinates for a toolpath. One of the things we love about makerbot in contrast to commercial printers is that you have complete control over every aspect of the print technique. We think there is a lot of opportunity to develop new printing styles with makerbots, beyond traditional solid prints. We wanted to experiment with the materiality of makerbot prints by working directly in gcode with processing, so we made this small library that provides some simple functions for generating gcode commands, and prints a gcode file. Library (v1.1.2):
http://diatom.cc/code/processing/libraries/codethread/codethread_1.1.2.zip Documentation:
http://diatom.cc/code/processing/libraries/codethread/reference/ Github Repository:
https://github.com/DiatomStudio/CodeThread/ Our experiments (including some description of the images attached here):
http://blog.diatom.cc/codethread It's still pretty fresh, hope to have some more updates and examples soon!

title: Customizable spool holder for M3D printer

description.text: This spool holder is intended for the Micro3D printer, and sits on top of the unit, above the extruder, and using the printer chassis as base. These are brackets only. Two sets are needed, one for each side, then simply add any dowel, rod or tubing of your choosing to complete this thing. Use the customizer on the right and select the tubing diameter you plan to use for the vertical risers and top axle, and the model will adapt. Be careful not to make the vertical fit too snug, or the brackets may split apart. The vertical risers can be anything that make it tall enough to clear the printer and fit your spool size, minimum 3" recommended; I use 6" vertical risers. The top brackets hold a horizontal axle, which can easily lift out to change filament. The horizontal top tube needs to be 6.25" in length, and can fit multiple spools. Update 20160110: the "Global" section in the scad file caused parameters to no longer display in December. This should now work again.
This is an evolution of a holder I made earlier (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:707089), and allows for customization to suit any size rod.

comments.text: This spool holder method has only caused me problems.  The weight of the spool is now hanging off of the top of your printer chassis.  When the print head moves around it causes the shaking to transfer up to the spool which in turn amplifies the shaking then causing the print head to shift print layers.  Once the weight of the spool was taken off of the printer chassis, the print accuracy returned.
comments.author: architectjon

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback architectjon. I've not had any issues myself with accuracy when using this setup, even when loaded with 3 lbs of filament; it has not made any difference for me. One thing I would check in your case: do you have excessive movement for your spindle, or is it a reasonably snug fit? If your fit is one the loose side, I can see how it could sway and introduce problems.

comments.author: DDW96

comments.text: I have had the M3D for two weeks, and so far I'm impressed. It's a very easy "out of box experience" because it's a pre-assembled injection molded printer so there's nothing to assemble other than loading filament. It's inexpensive, small, and very portable. And you can load filament internally, making it a very neat looking unit, good for (for example) putting in a kid's room. The trade-offs are that it's slow, has limited print area, and can't operate stand-alone - you need to drive it from a computer. I plan on taking it to Maker Faires, and to drive it from a cheap little WinBook tablet.  If you use their filament spools, they're tiny, but since you're only going to print small things it's a reasonable tradeoff. You can use full size filament spools externally, but not that a standard 1 KG spool of filament weighs more than the printer.
comments.author: DDW96

comments.text:
I'm impressed with it considering it's still going through a beta phase. The hardware appears to be well enough made, and it certainly looks nice, and while the software and printer worked out of the box for me, there are some rough edges still (mostly software). There was a new software release earlier today that may improve some things.
I've printed some small ornaments and figurines that came out really well.
It uses 1.75mm filament, but have had mixed results; so far only the included M3D PLA has worked consistently well for me.
All in all not bad at all for a $300 printer.
comments.author: DDW96

title: caulk saver cap (cap open tubes of caulk)

description.text: The cap will seal open tubes of caulk (10+ oz tubes and higher). It includes a center post to keep the caulk from drying inside the tip as well as a side clip to attach the cap to the push rod when not in use.

Build notes:

  • ABS is the better choice for this over PLA. It will withstand hot outdoor or in-vehicle temperatures and the center post has a chance of staying intact :-)

  • Do not try to print this in PLA with the center post. PLA is too brittle and vertically printed objects tend to snap off with very little shear force. Print the version without the post instead.

  • On my printer, the post was stronger when printed with 0.1mm layers vs 0.2mm.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ltce14mmtw9

This spool holder is designed especially for the Prusa I3 Steel, it allows rapid change of the spool, since it is enough to put it over.  
As it does not invade the front of the printer it does not cause interference with the extruder if the piece is very high.  
The horizontal bars are M8 threaded rod with 608 zz bearings at the lateral ends for smooth rotation.  
To keep the filament spool stable, I passed 2 aluminium pipes of 10mm external diameter over the bars.

Materials: 4- 608zz bearings 22x8x7 mm.
2- M8 threaded rods 256 mm long.
2- 10 mm external aluminium pipes 223 mm long.
8- 8 mm washer.
6- M8 lock nuts.
2- M8x25 screws

description.text: My fiance tasked me with cleaning the bathtub, before tomorrow night. Well, I made the ultimate error; I accidentally scrubbed one spot a little too hard and revealed to her that the actual stock color of my bathtub is not, in fact, off-white as I'd claimed, but white. I did some quick mental math and realized I'd just finish scrubbing up the entire tub by tomorrow night if I didn't need time to sleep and my arms wouldn't fall off in the meantime. So I came up with a way to make it go MUCH faster! I started out making a design for this, but as I got into it, I realized I already had a part on my shelf that was basically the same design... the old gear from this print: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6544 Which didn't work in practice due to my inability to properly hob a bolt. But it would work here.!

Print he gear, get an M8 bolt of appropriate length, and some zip-ties, and one of the scrubbing pads of the style you see here, or possibly one of the metal type.  
Put them all in a bag and shake it up until they fall into the proper configuration.
Or, to save time, construct manually to match the attached photos.
Use care in using this tool!  You're using a power tool in a place that's normally full of water.  Please be sure they do not come together!  Also keep an eye on the pad so it doesn't come loose or catch on anything.
I've used this, it works BRILLIANTLY.  It works even better with a paste of water and COMET or AJAX-type cleaner.

description.text: I wanted to throw an RGB led in Tothe's awesome "Giant Crystal" and had a 30mm diameter, 25mm high color changing LED laying around.  Printed at 5% infill with supports, then ripped the supports out of the LED chamber.  Pretty happy with it.

You're going to want a very low infill on these. I like around 5%.  
crystal_led_2.stl has a slightly higher top layer on the base, which lets less light out around the crystal and puts more light into the crystal.  
crystal_led.stl shines more light on the outside of the crystal, especially if printed at higher (30% or more) infill.

author: Romancovm

title: Brackets for assembling top enclosure for FlashForge Creator

description.text:
These are the necessary brackets for assembling an acrylic top enclosure for a FF Creator. You can buy the 0.093" Acrylic sheets from Home Depot and cut it to size. I basically made it fit on the lip of the top, overhanging the rear. There are 5 different brackets: 1) Front corner brackets - These cover the triangular holes on the front
2) Rear corner brackets - These cover the holes on the rear, as well as support the rear trays on the side
3) Rear support brackets - These support the rear trays from the back
4) Regular brackets - These just join the side and top pieces at regular intervals
5) Top corner pieces - These just support the corner of the top cover and squares up the corners Hopefully, you should be able to see where the pieces fit in the pictures. For details about the front door hinge and knob, go here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:731461

Designed to be printed with the spool rail horizontal.  Supports for the mounting tabs are required.

comments.text: Hi thedingus, these are a great idea, but I have found another creative and valid use of angling the motors. You may have heard of the dihedral wing profile,  a slight bend in the wing to make more stable? Well the angling of motors inwards, tilting toward the center of a symmetrical X Quad type frame makes for a very stable frame, it make for quicker  tight corners and also for descents, reduces the dirty air, or prop wash that is experienced. There is but one draw back! It is not as efficient. Big Deal I say !!! So I am hoping that these will be okay for use with a ~ 22mm motor mounted on the legendary HoverThings450 CF frame. 12 -16mm spacing  x 3mm screw. But will it support a motor with minimum 16mm bolt pattern please.

title: Simple connectors for playing with building framing models

description.text:
3/23 MAJOR UPDATE with a new hinged ridge connector and much simpler top plate connector. These print much faster and allow for different roof pitches. 3/21 updated with a new simpler top plate connector.
3/22 added a mirror of the bottom corner connector. Four connectors. They are scaled for 2x4s but could be easily adjusted for other dimensions. 56mm in the model = 1' in the real world. An 8' 2x4 (real dimensions of 1.5" x 3.5") would have the following dimensions at the connector scale. 2" x 4" x 8' = 7mm x 16.3mm x 448mm Some people may want the ridge beam connector to have the ridge beam cutout on top so I've included that as well. My thought is that having the beam on the bottom of the connector makes model building easier.

title: Airtripper bowden for E3D V6 Kit with Bowden AddOn

description.text:
The main concept behind the modification is the optimal PTFE tubing configuration. It follows E3D's recommendation : http://wiki.e3d-online.com/wiki/File:V6_Assembly_-_Half_a_Wades_Block.jpg
PTFE tube goes inside the extruder, reaching very close to MK8 gear.
Filament is exposed as little as possible for optimal flow. Tube stays stable and locked at both sides.
At outgoing side by the E3D plastic pneufit provided by "E3D full kit with bowden add-on" and by a M4 nut at ingoing side.
Be aware, M4 nut will press the PTFE tube making its I.D. narrower.
Dont forget to drill with 2mm bit inside the tube, for the whole narrow part of the tube, to restore its I.D. at 2mm as it should be.
Otherwise there will be an increasing friction bottleneck for filament flow. Extruder's base made longer to provide easy access at mounting holes.
The idea for this mod came from here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:661936 For my printer's extruder, I used and recommend this modified idler for more tension against mk8 gear and thus even better flow of filament: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:487891 Extruder results are satisfactory.
Tested with PLA and ABS, it can drive filament without any missing step even in higher speeds although my NEMA motor is not strong enough (holding torque 2550 g-cm). In action, printing an object at 70mm/s speed: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fvsaoYTabMs&feature=youtu.be My extruder's complete parts list, in case it helps anyone:
  • E3D V6 Full Kit with bowden add-on : http://e3d-online.com/E3D-v6/Full-Kit/v6-1.75mm-Universal-Bowden
  • Prusa i3 Rework X_Carriage from here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119616
  • Hotend mount with fans for level cooling: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:547706. For auto bed leveling there is a nice remix: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:757336
  • E3D V6 40mm Fan mount : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:506958
  • Two 50x50mm 12v fans for level cooling and One 40x40mm for E3D V6 Heatsink cooling
  • Coldend Bowden Extruder (this very thing): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:731585
  • Axle and Strut for cold-end from original Airtripper BSP Design : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:126778
  • Modified idler for extra tension : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:487891
  • MK8 Drive gear, 608ZZ bearing, M4 Nut, M3 Bolts and nuts, 2 springs
    • Hotend Fan Recommendation:
    I replaced original 30mm E3D fan with a 40x40x20 mm fan running at 7v instead of 12v.
    This way noise and hotend vibration of E3D fan is gone, producing better quality prints and less noise headaches.
    To get 7v from ATX PSU you can connect fan's negative to 5v and fan's Positive to 12v. Thanks to Airtripper for publishing this very nice piece of openSCAD source. Happy printing !
  • Original design : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:126778
    Please check Airtripper fantastic documentation for details.
    • Update 12-May-2015
    Redesign uploaded.
    Inbound and outbound PTFE holes are lowered by 0.5mm to eliminate tube declination.

title: Dial Indicator Mount for TAZ 5
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This bracket snaps snuggly on to the print head so that a dial indiator can be used to level the bed.The dial indicator used here was purchased at Harbor Freight and Tools.

This dial indicator mount works by snapping snuggly over the print head. With this mount you do not have to remove the print head to level the bed. However, since the indicator location is displaced from the print nozzle, you cannot get to all of the corners of the bed.  
Two tabs on the top of the mount slide over the notches at the top of the print head.  Notice there is a notch for the bolt protruding from the printer and there is a 2-step snap at the bottom (be careful the right ledge is to the rigth of the body of the print head on the bottom left edge).   
The dial indicator is held in place with a bolt.  
After the dial indicator is mounted, home the Z-axis and move the print head to four corners.  Adjust the bed so there is minimal bed height variation. I was able to get my bed to within 5/1000".   
This mount was printed using Cura. Before printing, be sure to rotate the object on the X-axis (green) and lay it flat to minimize overhang.

description.text: I am not going to say this is a great idea, but it will work :) I made this to mount a GoPro on top of my RCX H250CF-3K from MyRCmart. I found that for slow movements, this works great. For a little faster movements, I left an opening on the front so you can zip-tie it to the frame. You could even put a loose zip-tie in through this opening to tie the camera mount to the frame instead of relying on the rubber bushings entirely. Printed pretty tight on my Printrbot with .2mm layers in PLA I used http://www.thingiverse.com/3D_CC_design/about 's mount for the GoPro connection and married it to my new base.

The Tri-Stand is a solid, one-piece smartphone and tablet stand designed to have 3 angles for multiple use-cases:
1) A 70-degree angle to hold tablets upright, for viewing-mode or "desktop computer" mode
2) A 45-degree angle for touch-screen ease
3) a 30-degree angle to improve ergonomic use and reduce glare when writing/drawing on the screen with a stylus The stand was designed by 6th grade students at Calistoga Elementary School, specifically for use with Lenovo ThinkPad Tablet 2 devices. However, it also works with a variety of tablets including Samsung Galaxy Note, iPad, and others... Dimensions: 3" x 5 3/8" footprint x 1 11/16" high
Slot width (supported thickness of tablet): 7/16" http://www.TriStands.com
NOTE: This stand prints wonderfully -- no supports needed -- if you rotate it 90 degrees onto its side before printing.

Based on the FliteTest Anycopter/Electrohub design.  The scad file allows you to specify the outer diameter of the plates and gives you the option to create the mounting holes for either the OpenPilot CC3D or the HK KK2 boards.

I had begun designing this not knowing a machine already existed called the Bukito so I want to reference that for this build. I also want to reference the OpenBot on openbuilds. I wanted to make a printer that was as simple as possible with minimized parts count. I believe this can be assembled within a few hours! Deign goals were: Easy and fast to assemble
Minimized Parts Count
Stiff frame
Lower center of gravity
Portability It utilizes 2040 vslot and solid v-wheels. This was my first v-slot build and I'm really impressed with it. Very quiet and smooth linear motion. I will try to put together a BOM in the coming days and also a build manual if there's interest. Here's a video of it printing: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dnQ_Ru8LSPU I want to reference Sakunamary and Wersey for the controller mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:204962, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:87250. The extruder is derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:390020 by Oodaner.

You make the carriage plates by using a standard inkjet/laser printer and print off the drill template.   To do this, first install Inkscape.  Inskcape will be able to open and print the drill template dxf file. . Tape the drill template to your 1/8" aluminum blanks.  Use a center punch to punch the holes, then you can you use a drill press (or regular drill) to drill the holes.

description.text:
The wireless charging feature of Samsung Galaxy Note 3 is really neat. You can find a wireless charging kit as cheap as about 30$ like this: http://www.amazon.com/CHOETECH-Wireless-Compatible-Flip-Case-Charging/dp/B00FPFM4AY/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1426828718&sr=8-1&keywords=galaxy+note+3+wireless+charging
So every night you put your phone on the pad, next morning you get a fully charged phone. The problem is you have to put that small pad below the center on that large phone, or it will not work properly. So I created this thing. The charging pad should be perfectly slided in, then just put your phone on it for charging. It makes the wireless charging easier, and looks really cool even without a phone on it! Qi is a wireless charging standard, so this thing might work on other phones as well, as you might want to modify the model to make sure the charging pad is on the center of the phone. Print with 20%~30% infill, recommended shell thickness 0.8mm+. This model is designed to use a fair less amount of material, about 19.42m, 1.75mm diameter PLA on 20% infill, 1mm shell. The word on the photo model is added by the "3D Builder" from win8 app store...
Added 3/20/15: The .dwg file is created by AutoCAD student version 2015. Lower versions might be unable to open it.
Changed link (and price) to a fully usable Note 3 kit. The old link which include charging pad only can be searched by "Qi charging pad".

Print without support should works fine. My 3D printer is small so I have to print it vertically with support, but it works fine as well.
Just print it, slide the charging pad in and enjoy.

title: Repconn Rocket Souvenir from Fallout: New Vegas

description.text:
I based the height and scale off of a in game Pencil to real life scale. a non sharpened #2 pencil is 7" long. So I figured the ones in the game are sharpened so 6" sounded good.  
I have uploaded the full rocket if you have a large enough printer, or you can scale it down. I also broke the model into 3 pieces with sockets to insert each piece into for smaller machines.  
I also uploaded a image of the painted version from the game.  
Update: I did a better version of the complete rocket called it rocket_4_fin.stl it fixes a bug I seen where the fins meet the body.
You might have to sand the sockets to make the pieces sit flush.

title: Cosplay Unicorn Horn (inspired by My Little Pony)

description.text:
A show accurate cosplay horn for fans of the show, "My Little Pony".  
You are free to print / remix these for fun, but please contact me for licensing if you plan to sell them.

Configure your slicer to make the model "Hollow" and set the number of outer loops to 1. Notice that the model is slightly tilted. That tilt should be pointing upwards, so your horn doesn't look droopy. Attach to your forehead with double-sided foam tape, spirit gum, or an elastic band threaded through two small holes drilled on either side of the base of the horn. If your hair is long enough, it should be able to hide the elastic band and wrap around the horn, hiding its base. The "child" model is scaled to fit someone who is about 4ft tall.

comments.text: Just what I needed for Halloween.  Thanks!
comments.author: TimberWolf96

comments.text: May I ask, what program did you use?
comments.author: Ziuu

comments.text: I used a lesser-known remake of OpenSCAD called "ImplicitCAD".  It's capable of making some more organic shapes by incorporating a smoothing factor to all specified intersections.  In addition, it has some extra parameters for defining extruded structures that was useful for making the spiral cut along the length of the horn.

title: Jhead Mount to Ubis Hotend Adapter

description.text: I needed to use the printrbot's ubis hotend with a jhead mount (for a Smartrapcore). Unfortunatly, the grooves are not the same between the two. Fun fact, the smartrapcore's bracket is closer to a groovemount than a real Jhead. I've updated the STLs accordingly. Feel free to adapt to your own with the SCAD. Github source for SCAD: https://github.com/lordofhyphens/jheadtoubis

Print 2 copies and install onto the ubis, and then install the assembly where it expects a J-Head.  
The bowden are pre-set for 3mm OD tube with a nut trap, change the SCAD and remake the STLs if you need something different.  
The pushfit model should allow you to thread a M6 pushfit connector into the top after it's been bolted close.

author: lenoxjoseph

description.text: This is yet another example from my thesis in 94.  Every triangle is congruent to every other, and there are 6 at each vertex.  This surface can be folded from a plane.  This has the same symmetry group as an antiprism.
